newsitem.title: USA: NYS Silver says gov healthcare cuts will cost jobs.
newsitem.headline: NYS Silver says gov healthcare cuts will cost jobs.

text.p: New York State Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, D-Manhattan, said that big reductions in healthcare proposed by the governor would cost the state jobs in one of the state's few growth sectors.

"The governor's proposed tax cuts, which would mean $3 billion in lost possible revenues, would wipe out about 25,000 to 30,000 jobs in this state," said Silver. He made the comments in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.

"That's something the state cannot afford economically," said Silver, noting that from 1988 to 1993, when New York State state lost around 500,000 jobs due to a recession, the healthcare industry added employees.

Republican Gov George Pataki wants to cut around $820 million in healthcare in fiscal 1998, but the Democrat-led Assembly would restore all but about $100 million of these reductions. The state was due to approve a budget for fiscal 1998 by April 1, but failed to do so, in part due to divisions over such issues.

Silver showed no inclination of retreating from the Assembly's position that almost all of the governor's latest healthcare cuts must be put back. "It is absolutely essential that we restore it," he said.
